body:
What toolchain are you using? OS?

@ZihengJiang

You are using latest master, which is 0.10.1 and going through refactors.
Please checkout stable release from 0.10.0 tag. Also update submodule with `git submodule update`

> I will look into this. It will be great if we can use mxnet inside caret.

I'm looking forward to it. A lot of people have asked. I will probably try using to build a simple autoencoder for the [`recipes`](https://github.com/topepo/recipes) package too.
Perfect! Thanks

Hi @jmerkow 
SVM is a linear classifier with form WX + b and +1, -1 classification.
From the tutorial, there is a fully connect layer before svm layer, in current mxnet implementation, the output just forward the previous fully connect layer output(in the code F Identity). Maybe in other implementation or framework, the svm layer may store W, b and do the affine transform itself. 

From what I observe(I only looked at svmoutput), MXNet does not compute loss explicitly in the executor itself, so that's why we add the metric utils.

But I think it's not still convenient to compute loss due to lack of info in that way, it's easier to compute loss during forward pass.

How about we do the following:

merge mpsgd into sgd as a option. disabled by default
when weight is 16 bit, give a warning if the option is disabled and instruct the user to consider turning it on.
turn in on by default in image-classification example for fp16.
The dimension of predicts is 95040 which is smaller than 98940. Statement predicts[:98940] would give an index out of range error.

@topepo After this merged, can you write a small demo or tutorial on using MXNet inside caret?

That will be wonderful.

Sorry that pkg for R 3.3 hasn't been uploaded.

I will upload soon.

compression is not a good idea, but I just got a better idea to do partial weight update. It will change a lot code of kvstore related codes. 😄

I'm watching this PR. Looks good to me! Please merge.

weight=mx.sym.var('fc1_voc12_c3_weight', lr_mult=0.1)
fc1_voc12_c3=mx.symbol.Convolution(name='fc1_voc12_c3',data=conv_feat, weight=weight, kernel,(3,3),no_bias=True,num_filter=num_classes,dilate=24)

I had to modify the checkout command to get the dependencies which match the release

ie replaced `git clone https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet.git mxnet --recursive && git -C mxnet checkout v${MXNET_VERSION}` with ` git clone https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet.git mxnet --recursive --branch v${MXNET_VERSION} --depth 1`
Builds fine now :)

I guess you are using R 3.2. `endsWith` was introduced in R 3.3.

This is expected. We never upload the package to CRAN, so it can never be found on CRAN mirrors.

@nmatare In current implementation, your `data` and `label` should have the same dimensions just like what we have in the tutorial: http://dmlc.ml/rstats/2016/08/19/recurrent-models-and-examples-with-mxnet-r.html

```r
> dim(X.train.data)
[1]    32 31360
> dim(X.train.label)
[1]    32 31360
> dim(X.val.data)
[1]   32 3456
> dim(X.val.label)
[1]   32 3456
```

This depends on your network definition. If no gradient is needed along a path backward will not be called for that path

I'll upload the missing artifacts for 2.11 today. Scala 2.12 will be supported soon - tests required.

The functions InferShape and InferType could fail if users provide insufficient information. If it fails, the program continues with 0-size ndarrays and may cause segfaults.

I will add checks for shape and type inference results.

@gurumurthys Thanks my brother.

@winitzki Scalapkg actually supports CTCLoss. All the operators starts with ```_contrib_``` are under the
contrib package, so you can use the CTCLoss by 
```scala
import ml.dmlc.mxnet._
val ctcLoss = contrib.Symbol.CTCLOSS()()(Map(...))
```

And the Scalapkg uses macro to auto generate the symbol. So no needs to add symbols by hand. You can refer to #3217 for more details.

There is probably a scaling issue somewhere but the predictions coming out `self.mod.predict` are already cropped somehow:
```
[[ 9.          0.99957496  1.          1.          1.          1.        ]
 [ 9.          0.99943036  1.          1.          1.          1.        ]
 [ 9.          0.99912649  1.          1.          1.          1.        ]
 ..., 
 [ 9.          0.15663669  1.          1.          1.          1.        ]
 [ 9.          0.15572004  1.          1.          1.          1.        ]
 [ 9.          0.15441671  1.          1.          1.          1.        ]]
```

Ok, I found where the clipping was done: `mx.contrib.symbol.MultiBoxDetection` has an optional parameters `clip`. After setting it to `False` and scaling the detected rectangles correctly, I get the right results*:

![screen shot 2017-06-03 at 10 18 51 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/85865/26751996/4c6c6722-4846-11e7-8b88-9917d19dde66.png)

Do you think it would be worth adding an option to the SSD example to do inference on original image sizes? I can prepare a pull request for that.

* *I'm not sure what to think about the 3 false positives at the bottom.*
me too, same problem.
the last layer, such as softmax or proxy.
